generif.text: Endosialin colocalized with thrombomodulin, suggesting the proteins may have complementary functions in tumor progression.
Endosialin is a marker of stromal fibroblasts and is not selectively expressed on tumor endothelium.
results pinpoint to a molecular mechanism by which expression of endosialin/TEM1 in the tumor stroma and endothelium may support tumor progression and invasion

experiments unambiguously demonstrate that endosialin is expressed by tumor-associated myofibroblasts & mural cells & not by endothelial cells; results validate endosialin as marker of tumor-associated myofibroblasts & tumor vessel-associated mural cells
endosialin is not expressed in normal human adult brain but is strongly upregulated in the angiogenic vasculature of all high-grade glioma specimens examined
identified extracellular endosialin ligands and identified Mac-2 BP/90K as a specific interaction partner

expression of TEM1 or endosialin (CD248) and other TEM has been discovered in a population of vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2+/CD31+/CD45-/VE-cadherin+ EPC derived from human CD133+/CD34+ cells
endosialin is strongly expressed by pericytes during periods of active angiogenesis during embryonic and tumor development
These findings elucidate important aspects of endosialin gene regulation
TEM1/endosialin was induced in the vasculature of high-grade brain tumors where its expression was inversely correlated with patient age.
Results provide evidence for a TEM-1-dependent signal pathway that controls proliferation of pericytes.
Endosialin expression may be involved in the progression of rectal cancers.
CD248 defines a subset of stromal cells, including but not limited to some myofibroblasts, linked to albuminuria and tubulointerstitial damage during tissue remodeling in CKD.
endosialin can be detected in advanced sarcoma

[review] CD248 is a C-type lectin-like domain-containing cell surface glycoprotein that is expressed by stromal cells of proliferating tissues during embryogenesis and postnatally in tumors and inflammatory lesions.
new monoclonal antibodies described in this paper are domain-specific and represent important reagents for the study of functional contributions of extracellular endosialin domains
The genes CD248, Ephb1 and P2RY2 were detected as the top overexpressed in GC biopsies.
The authors show that endosialin, a C-type lectin, expressed in the liver exclusively by HSC and portal fibroblasts, is upregulated in liver fibrosis in mouse and man.
MORAb-004 reduced CD248 on pericytes, impaired tumor microvasculature maturation and ultimately suppressed tumor development.
TEM1 expression in cancer-associated fibroblasts is correlated with a poor prognosis in patients with gastric cancer
CD248 overexpression is possibly involved in the pathogenesis of IPF and it has potential as a disease severity marker.

Tumour cell endosialin expression was seen in 89% of undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcomas, 77% of adult fibrosarcomas/spindle cell sarcomas, 62% of synovial sarcomas, 51% of leiomyosarcomas and 31% of rhabdomyosarcomas.
the data demonstrate a critical role for endosialin-expressing primary tumor pericytes in mediating metastatic dissemination and identify endosialin as a promising therapeutic target in breast cancer
Data show that podoplanin (PDPN), CD106 (VCAM-1) and CD248 protein were increased in diseased compared to healthy tendon cells.
Endosialin is a potential regulator of phenotypic remodeling of vascular smooth muscle cells contributing to atherosclerosis.
These findings identify novel protein interactions involving CLEC14A, CD93 and CD248 with MMRN2 as targetable components of vessel formation

In addition to EIF2AK4, which has been already suggested to be associated with pulmonary veno-occlusive disease, we identified the novel candidate genes ATP13A3, CD248, EFCAB4B, involved in lung vascular remodeling that represent reliable drivers contributing to the disease according to their biological functions/inheritance patterns

CD248 exerts detrimental effects on WAT phenotype and systemic glucose homeostasis which may be reversed by suppression of adipocyte CD248. Therefore, CD248 may constitute a target to treat obesity-associated co-morbidities.
CD248 contributes to tumor growth, fibrosis, and neoplastic angiogenesis. (Review)
Data show that endosialin protein (CD248) gene silencing as well as miR-125b-5p overexpression markedly reversed drug resistance and inhibited epithelial-mesenchymal transition in colon cancer cells.
Role of tumor endothelial marker 1 (Endosialin/CD248) lectin-like domain in lipopolysaccharide-induced macrophage activation and sepsis in mice.
Placental and plasma early predictive biomarkers for gestational diabetes mellitus.
Tumor endothelial marker 1 is upregulated in heart after cardiac injury and participates in cardiac remodeling.
Fibroblast expression of CD248 may contribute to exacerbation of microvascular damage during systemic sclerosis.
CD248 Regulates Wnt Signaling in Pericytes to Promote Angiogenesis and Tumor Growth in Lung Cancer.
Endosialin-positive tumor-derived pericytes promote tumor progression through impeding the infiltration of CD8[+] T cells in clear cell renal cell carcinoma.
Inflammatory Mesenchymal Stem Cells Express Abundant Membrane-Bound and Soluble Forms of C-Type Lectin-like CD248.
[Expression of endosialin in human hypertrophic scars and its regulation on fibroblast phenotype].
TEM1/endosialin/CD248 promotes pathologic scarring and TGF-beta activity through its receptor stability in dermal fibroblasts.
IL-8 from CD248-expressing cancer-associated fibroblasts generates cisplatin resistance in non-small cell lung cancer.
Regulation of matrix reloading by tumor endothelial marker 1 protects against abdominal aortic aneurysm.

BP.term: positive regulation of endothelial cell apoptotic process

interpro.desc: Growth factor receptor cysteine-rich domain superfamily

name: CD248 molecule
summary: Predicted to enable extracellular matrix binding activity and extracellular matrix protein binding activity. Predicted to be involved in cell migration. Predicted to act upstream of or within several processes, including anatomical structure regression; lymph node development; and positive regulation of endothelial cell apoptotic process. Located in extracellular exosome. [provided by Alliance of Genome Resources, Apr 2022]
